(1983–present) }} '''Robert Wuhl''' (born October 9, 1951) is an American actor, comedian and writer.{{cite news|last=Brandes|first=Philip|date=24 October 2012|title=Review: 'I Ought to Be in Pictures' steeped in sentimentality|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/oct/24/entertainment/la-et-cm-review-i-ought-to-be-in-pictures-falcon-theatre-20121023|newspaper=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|access-date=24 March 2015}} He is best known as the creator and star of the television comedy series ''[[Arliss]]'' (1996–2002){{cite news|last=Sandomir|first=Richard|author-link=Richard Sandomir|date=1 April 2006|title=Robert Wuhl Is a Teacher on HBO's 'Assume the Position With Mr. Wuhl'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/01/arts/television/01wuhl.html|newspaper=''[[The New York Times]]''|access-date=24 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/otl/agents/wuhl.html|title=Wuhl: Anything goes|date=22 April 1999|website=[[Go.com]]|publisher=[[Disney Interactive]]|access-date=24 March 2015}} and for his portrayal of newspaper reporter Alexander Knox in [[Tim Burton]]'s ''[[Batman (1989 film)|Batman]]'' (1989). ==Early life== Wuhl was born in [[Union Township, Union County, New Jersey|Union, New Jersey]] to a Jewish family.{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/1989-08-11/entertainment/26146898_1_penn-teller-couple-of-eccentric-guys-cool-things|title=Rising Star Robert Wuhl Is Having Fun|last=Lloyd|first=Jack|date=11 August 1989|publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network|Philly.com]]|access-date=24 March 2015}}{{cite book |last1 = Samberg |first1 = Joel |year = 1998 |title = The Jewish Book of Lists |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iio5PewwIIwC&q=Robert+Wuhl+Jerry+McGuire |publisher = Carol Publishing Group |page = 99 |access-date = 2018-05-23 }} His father worked as a produce distributor.{{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/15/Robert-Wuhl.html |title=Robert Wuhl Biography (1951–)}} After attending [[Union High School (New Jersey)|Union High School]], Wuhl headed to the [[University of Houston]], where he was active in the drama department and the Epsilon-Omicron Chapter of [[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] Fraternity. Wuhl was awarded a Distinguished Alumni Award from his alma mater in April 2012. ==Career== Wuhl's first role in movies was a starring role in the 1980 comedy ''[[The Hollywood Knights]]'' along with other fledgling actors [[Tony Danza]], [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] and [[Fran Drescher]], followed by a small role in the film ''[[Flashdance]]'' (1983). Wuhl then had larger roles in movies including ''[[Good Morning, Vietnam]]'' (1987) with [[Robin Williams]],{{cite news|last=Hinson|first=Hal|date=15 January 1988|title='Good Morning, Vietnam'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/goodmorningvietnam.htm|newspaper=''[[The Washington Post]]''|access-date=24 March 2015}}''[[Bull Durham]]'' (1988) with [[Kevin Costner]], [[Tim Burton]]'s 1989 ''[[Batman (1989 film)|Batman]]'' (as reporter Alexander Knox) with [[Michael Keaton]], ''[[Blaze (1989 film)|Blaze]]'' (1989) with [[Paul Newman]], ''[[Missing Pieces (film)|Missing Pieces]]'' (1991) with [[Eric Idle]], ''[[Mistress (1992 film)|Mistress]]'' (1992) with [[Robert De Niro]], ''[[Blue Chips]]'' (1994) with [[Nick Nolte]], and ''[[Cobb (film)|Cobb]]'' (1994) with [[Tommy Lee Jones]].{{cite news|last=Turan|first=Kenneth|author-link=Kenneth Turan|date=2 December 1994|title=MOVIE REVIEWS : 'Cobb': What Becomes a Legend Least? : Shelton's Latest Film Shows Bad and Ugly of Baseball Star|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-12-02/entertainment/ca-3918_1_ty-cobb|newspaper=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|access-date=24 March 2015}}{{cite news|last=Barra|first=Allen|author-link=Allen Barra|date=9 October 2001|title=Clemens: The Greatest of All Time|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2001-10-09/news/clemens-the-greatest-of-all-time/|newspaper=''[[The Village Voice]]''|access-date=24 March 2015}} He wrote two of the six episodes for the TV series ''[[Police Squad!]]'' in 1982, and did an [[audio commentary]] for its release on DVD in 2006. Wuhl appeared with [[Keith Carradine]] in the 1985 music video to [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s hit "[[Material Girl]]". In 1992, he appeared in ''[[The Bodyguard (1992 film)|The Bodyguard]]'' as host of the [[Academy Awards|Oscars]]. In reality he won two [[Emmy Awards]] for co-writing the Academy Awards in 1990 and 1991 with [[Billy Crystal]]. From 1996 to 2002 he wrote and starred in the [[HBO]] series ''[[Arliss|Arli$$]]'' as the title character, an agent for high-profile athletes.{{cite news|last=Nocera|first=Joe|author-link=Joe Nocera|date=12 March 2012|title=The Case for Agents|url=http://nocera.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/03/12/the-case-for-agents/|newspaper=''[[The New York Times]]''|access-date=24 March 2015}} From 2000 to 2001, he was a frequent panelist on the [[ESPN]] game show [[2 Minute Drill (game show)|2 Minute Drill]], often quizzing the contestants on sports-related movies. Wuhl was a player in the [[Game Show Network]]'s ''[[Poker Royale]]'' series, a competition between pros and comedians. In 2006, he starred on HBO in a one-man-show, ''[[Assume the Position with Mr. Wuhl]]'', where he taught a history class to show how history is created and propagated in a similar fashion to pop culture. A second chapter entitled ''[[Assume the Position 201 with Mr. Wuhl]]'' aired on HBO in July 2007. Wuhl is currently developing a stage adaptation of "Assume the Position" at Ars Nova in New York City. He also hosted a sports, sports business and entertainment daily talk radio show,{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Christopher|date=20 May 2011|title='Juan and John' opening crowd includes John Roseboro's widow|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2011/05/juan-and-john-opening-crowd-includes-john-roseboros-widow.html|newspaper=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|access-date=24 March 2015}} for Westwood One (now [[Dial Global]]) from January through December 2011. Wuhl occasionally fills in for [[Boomer Esiason]] on the ''[[Boomer and Carton]]'' show. He played a judge on the TNT series ''[[Franklin & Bash]]''. He played Herb Tucker in a revival of the comedy-drama play ''[[I Ought to Be in Pictures]]''. In 2015, Wuhl portrayed himself on ''[[American Dad!]]'', in the episode "Manhattan Magical Murder Mystery Tour".
